choices.text: It is the branch of medial cord of brachial plexus.
It passes through quadrangular space along with posterior circumflex artery.
It provide sensory innervations to skin over medial side of arm and forearm.

questions.text: A 60 years old female visited to emergency department after slipping and falling on an outstretched hand. She had a pain in her shoulder and she unable to abduct her arm. Doctor found swelling and tenderness over proximal humerus on physical examination. X ray revealed fracture of surgical neck of humerus. Which of the following statement is true for injured nerve?
questions.solution:
• The injured nerve in above case is Axillary nerve.
  • Fracture of surgical neck of humerus leads to injury to axillary nerve which lead to paralysis of deltoid muscle and produce flat shoulder.
  • Axillary nerve (Circumflex nerve): smaller terminal branch of posterior cord of brachial plexus. (C5,C6).It courses through lower part of axilla into quadrangular space where it terminates by dividing into two branches:
  1. Anterior branch : supply deltoid and skin over its anteroinferior part.
  2. Posterior branch : supplies teres minor and posterior part of deltoid and continues as upper lateral cutaneous nerve of arm.
  • Axillary nerve may be damaged by dislocation of shoulder or by fracture of surgical neck of humerus. The effects produced are:
    • Rounded contour of shoulder is lost
    • Deltoid paralysed with loss of power of abduction up to 90 degree.
    • sensory loss over lower half of deltoid in a badge like area called regimental badge.


Option A : it is the branch of posterior cord of brachial plexus

Option c : it supply teres minor muscle

Option D : it provide sensory innervation to skin over lateral side of arm

Key takeaways: The axillary nerve, a terminal branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus (C5, C6), supplies the deltoid and teres minor muscles, and damage to it (e.g., by shoulder dislocation or humeral fracture) results in deltoid paralysis, loss of shoulder contour, and sensory loss over the regimental badge area.

questions.text: Which of the following pair is incorrect for joint of hand and its type?
questions.solution:
1st Capometacarpal joint is saddle variety of synovial joint.

The joints are structurally classified into three types:

  1. Fibrous joint: Here bones forming the joints are united by fibrous connective tissue.
  2. Cartilaginous joint: Here bones forming the joint are united by hyaline or fibrocartilage.
  3. Synovial joint: These joints possess a cavity and the articular ends of bones forming the joint are enclosed in a fibrous capsule. Synovial joint are classified according to shapes of articular surfaces:

A. Plane Joints: Intercarpal, Intertarsal, Intermetatarsal, Intermetacarpal

B. Hinge Joints: Interphalangeal, Elbow, Knee, Ankle

C. Pivot joints: Superior radioulnar, median atlantoaxial

D. Condylar joints: TM joints, Knee

E. Ellipsoid Joints: Wrist, Atlanto occipital, Metacarpo- phalangeal

F. Saddle Joints: 1st carpometacarpal, sterno-clavicular, incudo-malleolar,

G. ball and socket Joints: Hip, Shoulder, Incudo-stapedial

Key takeaways:

choices.text: Scaphoid is the most commonly fractured carpal bone.
Capitate is the largest carpal bone.
Pisiform is the last carpal bone to ossify.
Hamate has groove and crest on its palmar surface.

questions.text: True for carpal bones except
questions.solution:
- The carpus consists of the eight carpal bones which are arranged in two rows:

Mnemonic: She Looks Too Pretty Try To Catch Her

The proximal row: Scaphoid, Lunate, Triquetral, Pisiform

The Distal row: Trapezium, trapezoid, Capitate, Hamate

Key takeaways:

Identification and characteristics of carpal bones are as under:

choices.text: Colles' fracture : Lower end of Humerus
Chauffer's fracture: Styloid process of radius.
Boxer's fracture : Lower end of Ulna

questions.text: Which of the following pair is correct for name of fracture and related bone?
questions.solution: • Various fractures and related bones are as under

choices.text: A plexus of lymph vessels deep to areola is called subareolar plexus of sappey.
The lymph from lateral quadrant of breast is drained into anterior axillary lymph node.
About 25% of the lymph from the breast is drained into axillary lymph nodes.
Superficial lymphatic drain the skin of the breast except nipple and areola.

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct for lymphatic of Breast except
questions.solution:
• The knowledge of lymphatic drainage of breast is of great significance to surgeons because carcinoma of the breast spreads mostly through lymphatic.
  • Lymph nodes draining the breast:
    • Axillary lymph nodes: divides into five groups: Anterior, Posterior, Central, Lateral, Apical
    • Internal mammary nodes: along the internal thoracic vessels
    • Supraclavicular nodes:
    • Posterior intercostal nodes:
    • Cephalic (deltopectoral) nodes:
  • Lymphatic draining the breast:
    • Superficial lymphatics: Drain the skin of the breast except nipple and areola.
    • Deep Lymphatics: drain the parenchyma of the breast, and skin of the nipple and areola.
  • A plexus of lymph vessels deep to areola is called subareolar plexus of Sappey.
  • About 75% of the lymph from breast is drained into axillary nodes, 20% into internal mammary nodes and 5% into posterior intercostal lymph nodes.
  • The lymph from lateral quadrants of breast is drained into anterior axillary or pectoral group.
  • The lymph form medial quadrants is drained into internal mammary lymph nodes.
  • The few lymph vessels from the lower lateral quadrants drain into posterior intercostal nodes.

Key takeaways: most common quadrant for Brest cancer is upper outer quadrant, majority of lymph from breast goes into axillary nodes.

questions.text: All of the following structure piercing the clavipectoral fascia except
questions.solution:
• Clavipectoral fascia is a strong fascial sheet deep to the clavicular head of the pectoralis major filling space between the clavicle and pectoralis minor muscle.
  • Vertically, it extends from clavicle above to axillary fascia below.
  • Medially, it is attached to first rib and costoclavicular ligament.
  • Laterally, it is attached to coracoid process and blends with coracoclavicular ligament.

Key takeaways:

Structures piercing the clavipectoral fascia : (CLAP)

  1. Cephalic vein
  2. Lymphatics ( From breast to apical group of axillary lymph node)
  3. Acromiothoracic artery (Thoracoacromial artery)
  4. Pectoral nerve (Lateral)

questions.text: Which of the following markings is incorrect in the given image?
questions.solution:
The above image is of rotator cuff muscles.

  • The four of scapulohumeral muscles are called rotator cuff muscles for they form musculotendinous cuff around Glenohumeral joint: SITS muscles
    1. Supraspinatus
    2. Infraspinatus
    3. Teres minor
    4. Subscapularis
  • The rotator cuff plays an important role in stabilizing the shoulder joint during its movements.
  • The primary function is to grasp the relatively large head of the humerus and hold it against a smaller, shallow glenoid cavity.

choices.text: L4 - Highest point on iliac crest

questions.text: Which of the following pair is incorrect for vertebral spine and surface landmark on the back?
questions.solution: • The approximate levels of spines on back of the body are as under :

questions.text: A 15 years old boy came to hospital after fell from bicycle. He had a Supracondylar fracture of humerus. Above elbow cast was given to him. Now after removal of his cast, he complaint of weakness and inability to extends fingers. His forearm appears thin & wasted on examination. His hand is in a fixed position and claw like deformity of fingers. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Volkmann's ischemic contracture

  • The sudden occlusion of brachial artery due to tight plaster or its laceration due to supracondylar fracture of humerus.
  • Fibrosis of muscles of forearm due to ischemia and necrosis.
  • Fibrous muscles shorten permanently.
  • Flexor deformity skin to claw hand characterized by flexion of wrist, extension of MP Joints and flexion of IP joints.
  • Dupuytren's contracture:
    • Progressive fibrosis in medial part of the palmar aponeurosis.
    • The medial part of aponeurosis may undergo progressive thickening to form permanent contracture, resulting flexion deformity of little and ring fingers.

Trigger finger:

  • Finger gets locked in full flexion and can be extended suddenly and with a click only after excessive efforts.
  • Due to localized thickening of fibrous flexor sheath of digit.

de Quervain's disease:

  • Thickening of sheath around tendon of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.
  • Pain on lateral side of wrist

Key takeaways : Volkmann's ischemic contracture is a deformity from forearm muscle necrosis due to brachial artery occlusion, leading to a claw-like hand posture.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true for marked vein ?
I - It begins as continuous of lateral end of the dorsal venous arch.
II - It drains into axillary vein
III - It unites with brachial vein to become continuous with axillary vein
IV - It is accompanied by lateral cutaneous nerve of forearm.
questions.solution:
The marked vein is Cephalic vein.

  • The cephalic vein is superficial vein of upper limb.
  • The cephalic vein begins as the continuation of lateral end of dorsal venous arch.
  • It crosses roof of the anatomical box, ascends on the radial border of forearm, upwards in front of elbow runs in deltopectoral groove and drains into axillary vein.
  • The Cephalic vein is accompanied by the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm.
  • The cephalic vein is the preaxial vein of upper limb and corresponds to great saphenous vein of lower limb.
  • The basilic vein begins as medial end of dorsal venous arch of the hand. It pierces deep fascia, unites with brachial veins and runs along medial side of brachial artery to become continuous with axillary vein.

Key takeaway: The cephalic vein, a superficial vein of the upper limb, originates from the dorsal venous arch, ascends along the radial forearm, passes through the deltopectoral groove, and drains into the axillary vein.

choices.text: Brachial artery passes from medial side of arm to its anterior aspect.
Basilic vein pierces the deep fascia.
Radial nerve pierces the medial intermuscular septum to pass from posterior to anterior compartment.

questions.text: Following are the anatomical events at the insertion of coracobrachialis except
questions.solution:
Anatomical events at the insertion of coracobrachialis:

  • Circular shaft of humerus becomes triangular below this level
  • Brachial artery passes from medial side of arm to its anterior aspect
  • Basilic vein pierces the deep fascia.
  • Median nerve crosses in front of brachial artery from lateral to medial side.
  • Radial nerve pierces lateral intermuscular septum to pass from posterior to anterior compartment
  • Ulnar nerve pierces medial intermuscular septum to go into posterior compartment.
  • Medial cutaneous nerve of arm and forearm pierces the deep fascia.
  • Nutrient artery pierces the humerus.
  • Key takeaways: Radial nerve pierces lateral intermuscular septum to pass from posterior to anterior compartment.

choices.text: Median nerve - Brachial artery - Biceps tendon - Radial nerve
Median nerve - Biceps tendon - Brachial artery - Radial nerve
Radial nerve - Brachial artery - Biceps tendon - Median nerve
Median nerve - Brachialis - Brachial artery - Radial nerve

questions.text: Which of the following arrangement are true for content of cubital fossa from medial to lateral side ?
questions.solution:
Cubital fossa :

- It is a triangular hollow in front of the elbow.

- Boundaries :

  • Lateral : medial border of brachioradialis
  • medial : lateral border of pronator teres
  • Base : Imaginary line joining two epicondyle
  • Floor : Brachialis and supinator
  • Roof : Skin, superficial fascia, Deep fascia, Bicipital aponeurosis

- Contents : From medial to lateral side . Mnemonics - MBBR

  • Median nerve
  • Brachial artery
  • Biceps tendon
  • Radial Nerve

questions.text: A 30 years old cricket player came to orthopaedic with complaint of pain on the outer part of his right elbow. On examination, there is tenderness over lateral epicondyle and pain with resisted wrist extension. There is no history of trauma. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tennis Elbow : (lateral epicondylitis)

  • Pain and tenderness over lateral epicondyle of humerus
  • Pain during abrupt Pronation
  • Due to sprain of lateral collateral ligament of elbow joint
  • Due to tear of fibres of extensor carpi radialis brevis
  • Due to inflammation of bursa underneath ECRB
  • Due to strain or tear of common extensor origin

Golfer's elbow: Medial epicondylitis:

  • Pain and tenderness over medial epicondyle of humerus
  • Due to strain or tear of common flexor origin with subsequent inflammation
  • Due to repetitive use of superficial flexors of forearm

Student's elbow: (Miner's elbow):

  • Round fluctuating painful swelling over the olecranon.
  • Due to inflammation of subcutaneous olecranon bursa over subcutaneous area on the posterior aspect of the olecranon process

Nursemaid's elbow: Pulled elbow/Subluxation of head of radius

  • occurs in 1-3 years child
  • When the forearm is suddenly pulled in Pronation
  • The head of radius comes out of annular ligament
  • The elbow is kept slightly flexed and pronated

Key takeaways: fibres of extensor carpi radialis brevis is involved in tennis elbow

questions.text: A 50 years old chronic crutch user man visited to hospital with complaint of inability to grip any object in hand. Doctor noticed a loss of extension at elbow, wrist and Interphalangeal joints on examination. He also had sensory loss in arm, Forearm and hand region. Which nerve is most likely to involve in above case ?
questions.solution:
• Radial nerve : It is the largest branch of posterior cord of brachial plexus with root value of C5-C8 and T1. It supplies triceps muscle in arm region and supplies all extensor muscles at back of forearm.
  • Radial nerve is also supplies skin of back of arm (through posterior cutaneous nerve of arm) , posterior surface of forearm (through posterior cutaneous nerve of forearm )and lateral 2/3 of dorsum of hand and lateral three and half fingers ( superficial radial nerve).

Key takeaways:

questions.text: A 46 years old female visited to doctor with complaint of a change in the nipple size of her left breast. On physical examination, Doctor found a painless hard lump ( swelling) adherent to underlying tissue and immobile. The examination revealed retraction of the nipple, peau d' orange appearance of skin & enlarged axillary lymph nodes. What is the diagnosis in this case ?
questions.solution:
Carcinoma of breast:

- It is the most common cancer in females. It arises from the epithelial cells lining the lactiferous ducts.

- It presents with following signs and symptoms:

  • Presence of painless hard lump
  • Breast becomes fixed and immobile: due to infiltration of suspensory ligaments by cancer cells
  • Retraction of skin: due to infiltration of suspensory ligaments by cancer cells.
  • Retraction of nipple: due to infiltration and fibrosis of lactiferous ducts.

Peau d' orange appearance of skin: because pits of hair follicle appears to be retracted beneath the level of obstruction of superficial lymphatics.

questions.text: A 50 years old diabetic female visited to doctor with complaint of burning sensation and numbness in her hand for last 6 weeks mostly in night. On examination doctor found sensory and motor deficits i.e. hypoesthesia over the palmar aspect of lateral three and half finger and wasting of the thenar eminence. What is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Carpal tunnel syndrome : The median nerve is injured in the carpal tunnel due to its compression and produces a clinical condition called carpal tunnel syndrome.
  • The median nerve gets compressed in tunnel due to its narrowing following number for pathological conditions : Tenosynovitis of flexor tendons, Myxoedema, Retention of fluid in pregnancy, fracture dislocation of lunate bone.

Clinical features :

  • Feeling of burning pain along sensory distribution of median nerve.( lateral three and half digits)
  • Weakness of thenar muscles
  • Ape-thumb deformity

Key takeaways :

questions.text: During a neurological examination, the doctor asked a patient to hold a piece of paper between the two adjacent fingers and check it firmness by pulling the paper. Which of the following nerve is tested by doctor ?
questions.solution:
• The patient cannot hold a sheet of paper between 2nd and 3rd digit due to paralysis of palmar interossei muscle as palmar interossei are adductor of digits at metacarpophalangeal joint.
  • All four palmar interossei are supplied by deep branch of ulnar nerve.
  • Ulnar nerve: It is the main nerve of the hand and enters the palm by passing superficial to flexor retinaculum. It divided into superficial and deep branch.
  • Superficial branch: It supplies palmaris brevis muscle and supply skin of medial one and half digits.
  • Deep branch: It passes between abductor and flexor digiti minimi and than between opponens digiti minimi and fifth metacarpal bone, lying on hook of hemate. It gives muscular branches to
  1. Three hypothenar muscle
  2. Medial 2 lumbricals and 8 interossei (4 palmar interossei and 4 dorsal interossei)
  3. Adductor pollicis

key takeaways: The deep branch of the ulnar nerve supplies all four palmar interossei, three hypothenar muscles, medial two lumbricals, adductor pollicis, and the skin of the medial one and a half digits.

choices.text: I - Abductor pollicis longus, Extensor pollicis brevis
II - Extensor carpi radialis longus, Extensor carpi radialis brevis

questions.text: Which of the following pair is incorrect for compartment of Extensor retinaculum and structure passing deep to it ?
questions.solution:
Extensor Retinaculum:

  • Deep fascia on the back of the wrist is thickened to form oblique fibrous band
  • Medially attached to: styloid process of the ulna, Triquetral, pisiform
  • Laterally attached to: Lower part of anterior border of the radius
  • The space deep to extensor retinaculum is divided into six compartment by five septa.
  • The compartments are numbered I to VI from lateral to medial side.

questions.text: A 19 years old boy was operated for fracture proximal end of radius after fall from the cycle. After a week, he complaint of weakness in extension of wrist and extension of fingers. Which of the following nerve is most likely involved ?
questions.solution:
Posterior Interosseous nerve:

  • It is the deep terminal branch of the radial nerve.
  • It begins in the cubital fossa at the level of lateral epicondyle.
  • It leaves the cubital fossa by winding around the lateral side of neck of radius.
  • It supplies the all muscles of back of forearm except brachioradialis, extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL) and anconeus.
  • Since the ECRL is spared wrist drop does not occur.
  • It mostly damaged during the surgical exposure of the head of the radius, in fracture of proximal end of radius.

Key takeaways: posterior interosseous nerve is purely motor nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles tendons are inserted into dorsal digital expansion except
questions.solution:
Dorsal digital expansion/ Extensor expansion

  • It is a small triangular aponeurosis covering the dorsum of the proximal phalanx.
  • Its base covers the metacarpophalangeal (MP) joint.
  • The main tendon of the extensor digitorum occupies the central part of extension.
  • The posterolateral corners are joined by tendons of the interossei and of Lumbrical muscles.
  • The points of attachment of interossei and Lumbrical are called Wing Tendons.
  • Near Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint, the extensor tendon divides into central slip and two collateral slips. The central slip crosses PIP joint and inserted on dorsum of the base of middle phalanx. The collateral slips join each other and inserted into dorsum of base of distal phalanx.


Key takeaways:

The dorsal digital expansion is a triangular aponeurosis on the dorsum of the proximal phalanx, where the extensor digitorum tendon, interossei, and lumbrical muscles converge, with attachments forming wing tendons and divisions leading to insertions on the middle and distal phalanges.

questions.text: A 30 years old mother suddenly pulled her son away by holding his left hand to avoid fall while crossing the road. The child cried out and later refused to use his left upper limb. She visited doctor and doctor noticed that child held his left forearm in a semi flexed and pronated position. What is the most probable diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
Nursemaid's elbow : Pulled elbow/Subluxation of head of radius

  • occurs in 1-3 years child
  • When the forearm is suddenly pulled in Pronation
  • The head of radius comes out of annular ligament
  • The elbow is kept slightly flexed and pronated

Tennis Elbow: (lateral epicondylitis)

  • Pain and tenderness over lateral epicondyle of humerus
  • Pain during abrupt Pronation
  • Due to Sprain of lateral collateral ligament of elbow joint
  • Due to tear of fibres of extensor carpi radialis brevis
  • Due to inflammation of bursa underneath ECRB
  • Due to strain or tear of common extensor origin

Golfer's elbow: Medial epicondylitis:

  • Pain and tenderness over medial epicondyle of humerus
  • Due to strain or tear of common flexor origin with subsequent inflammation
  • Due to repetitive use of superficial flexors of forearm

Student's elbow: (Miner's elbow):

  • Round fluctuating painful swelling over the olecranon.
  • Due to inflammation of subcutaneous olecranon bursa over subcutaneous area on the posterior aspect of the olecranon process

questions.text: A 50 years old male presented with an inability to move finger of his left hand. He cannot extend ring and little finger of his left hand. Doctor noticed a thick cord at base of the ring finger. Which is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
- Dupuytren's contracture :

  • Progressive fibrosis in medial part of the palmar aponeurosis.
  • The medial part of aponeurosis may undergo progressive thickening to form permanent contracture, resulting flexion deformity of little and ring fingers.

Trigger finger:

  • Finger gets locked in full flexion and can be extended suddenly and with a click only after excessive efforts.
  • Due to localized thickening of fibrous flexor sheath of digit.

Mallet finger:

  • The insertion of extensor tendon into base of distal phalanx may be torn by forceful blow on tip of finger.
  • Distal phalanx assumes a flexed position with swan neck deformity. It occurs in cricketers and baseball players.

Volkmann's ischemic contracture

  • The sudden occlusion of brachial artery due to tight plaster or its laceration due to supracondylar fracture of humerus.
  • Fibrosis of muscles of forearm due to ischemia and necrosis.
  • Fibrous muscles shorten permanently.

Key takeaways: Dupuytren's contracture is associated with Peyronie's Disease, Frozen Shoulder, Trigger Finger

questions.text: A 65 years old diabetic male visited to doctor with complaint of progressive increasing pain in right shoulder. He also complaint of stiffness and limited range of movement in the joint. What is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Frozen shoulder (adhesive capsulitis) : clinical condition characterized by pain and uniform limitation of all movements of shoulder joint.
  • occurs due to shrinkage of the joint capsule.
  • The surrounding muscles shows disuse atrophy.
  • Pathologically there is fibroelastic proliferation in capsule that leads to formation of adhesions and consequent stiffness and pain on attempted movements.
  • The disease is self limiting and the patient may recover spontaneously by physiotherapy.

questions.text: A 45 years old female with history of operated carcinoma breast last month visited to hospital with complaint of bony swelling on left side of the back. On physical examination, the doctor found prominent medial border of the left scapula. The swelling became more prominent when she push the wall against resistance. What is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Winging of scapula: Inferior angle and medial border of scapula become unduly prominent when patient pushes his hands against wall.
  • It is due to injury to long thoracic nerve.
  • Causes : stab injury, during removal of breast tumors
  • Long thoracic nerve is arise from C5,C6,C7 roots of brachial plexus, passes behind clavicle and superficial to 1st and 2nd ribs. It continues to descend longitudinally along side of thoracic wall, in mid axillary line on superficial surface of serratus anterior.

Key takeaways : Winging of the scapula, caused by long thoracic nerve injury leads to prominence of the scapula's inferior angle and medial border when pushing against a wall.

choices.text: Anterior group: upper half of the trunk anteriorly and major part of breast
Posterior group: Upper half of the trunk posteriorly and axillary tail of breast
Lateral group: Upper and outer parts of breast
Central group: from other group of lymph node

questions.text: Which of the following pair is incorrect for axillary lymph nodes and their draining area ?
questions.solution:
Axillary Lymph Nodes:

  • They are scattered in the fibrofatty tissue of the axilla.
  • Their number varies between 20 and 30.
  • They are divided into five groups:

A. Anterior or Pectoral group:

  • Lie along lateral thoracic vein
  • receive lymph from upper half of the trunk and major part of breast.

B. Posterior or subscapular group:

  • Lies along the subscapular vein
  • Receive lymph from the upper half of the trunk posteriorly and axillary tail of breast

C. Lateral group:

  • Lies along upper part of humerus in relation to axillary vein
  • Drain lymph from the upper limb.

D. Central group:

  • Situated in the upper part of axilla
  • Receive lymph from other group and drain into apical group

E. Apical group:

  • 5 to 6 in number and lies posterior to pectoralis minor muscle
  • Receive lymph directly from upper and outer part of breast and indirectly from rest of breast

Key takeaways: The axillary lymph nodes, numbering 20 to 30, are grouped into anterior (pectoralis), posterior (subscapular), lateral, central, and apical nodes, draining various regions of the upper trunk, breast, and upper limb.

questions.text: Question
questions.solution:
Axillary Lymph Nodes:



  • They are scattered in the fibrofatty tissue of the axilla.

  • Their number varies between 20 and 30.

  • They are divided into five groups:


A. Anterior or Pectoral group:



  • Lie along lateral thoracic vein

  • receive lymph from upper half of the trunk and major part of breast.


B. Posterior or subscapular group:



  • Lies along the subscapular vein

  • Receive lymph from the upper half of the trunk posteriorly and axillary tail of breast


C. Lateral group:



  • Lies along upper part of humerus in relation to axillary vein

  • Drain lymph from the upper limb.


D. Central group:



  • Situated in the upper part of axilla

  • Receive lymph from other group and drain into apical group


E. Apical group:



  • 5 to 6 in number and lies posterior to pectoralis minor muscle

  • Receive lymph directly from upper and outer part of breast and indirectly from rest of breast

Key takeaways: The axillary lymph nodes, numbering 20 to 30, are grouped into anterior (pectoralis), posterior (subscapular), lateral, central, and apical nodes, draining various regions of the upper trunk, breast, and upper limb.
